Award.AwardTitle: Robust Design to Account for Geometric Imperfections in Small-Scale Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a design methodology with robust shape and topology optimization (RSTO) that accounts for various forms of geometric uncertainties in association with imperfections in manufacturing small-scale structures. The research will provide a level-set based dynamic topological design model that conveniently captures various forms of local and global geometric uncertainties. A computational framework for probabilistic topology design will be developed to integrate high performance uncertainty propagation techniques with existing deterministic topology optimization methods. The design testbed addresses the critical demand in sustainable energy source through the design of optical metamaterials. The seamless integration of the nano-fabrication and the RSTO methodology that requires no post processing of geometry boundary offers 'hardware-in-the-loop' validation using fully functional prototypes.

If successful, the proposed research will transform existing techniques in deterministic topology optimization to new methods for simultaneous shape and topology optimization under geometric uncertainties. Although the testbed is focused on a nano-engineered system, the methodology is general and widely applicable to handling geometric uncertainties at micro, meso, and macro scales where geometric variations have a large impact on product performance. The fruition of this research will offer a unique research and educational environment for multidisciplinary researchers across the fields of design and nano-manufacturing while training students in an interdisciplinary learning environment. The metamaterial design applications developed from this research will serve as excellent examples for promoting engineering awareness in K-12 by illustrating what is new in engineering and its impact on creating a sustainable environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a design methodology with simultaneous robust shape and topology optimization (RSTO) to account for various forms of geometric uncertainties in association with imperfections in manufacturing small-scale structures.  Highly efficient light-trapping structures for thin-film solar cells have been developed using the proposed topology optimization based design.  Topology optimization technique provides seamless integration of the nano-fabrication and design automation that requires no post processing of geometry boundary.  This also offers “hardware-in-the-loop” proof of concepts for validation using fully functional prototypes.


This research project extends the robust design principle to designing high-quality materials and device systems against geometric variations associated with the imperfections of micro/nano-manufacturing processes without incurring the high cost of improving the precision of fabrication processes.  Through our research, existing techniques in deterministic topology optimization have been transformed to new methods for simultaneous shape and topology optimization under geometric uncertainties.  The methodology implemented in our research based on genetic algorithm is first time ever being used in designing solar cells. The achieved light absorption efficiency is significantly beyond the reach of intuitive design and what existing in literature. The resulting efficient light trapping structures is expected to not only lead to a dramatic cost reduction in photovoltaic technology, but also provide a tangible application testbed for the further development of the scalable nanomanufacturing technology.


Applying topology optimization to designing robust micro/nano systems such as metamaterials and MEMS devices will likely benefit the design of emerging engineered materials systems where material structure has a large impact on the system performance, It will therefore stimulate growth in a broader spectrum of high technology industries such as the multi-billion dollar medical, consumer electronics, telecommunications, and related industrial markets. Although the testbed is focused on nano-engineered systems, the methodology is general and widely applicable to handling geometric uncertainties in engineering products at micro, meso, and macro scales. Examples of potential applications include microfluidic channel design that involves fabrication imperfections, design of material microstructure with inherent random behavior, and design of aircraft turbine blade with geometric variations on the surface that directly affects engine aerodynamic-structural performance.  Beyond engineering design, the methods developed will benefit other disciplines (e.g. medical imaging, computational mechanics), where a reduced set of descriptors is sought for representing complex geometries and the mapping of physical quantities between different manifolds is needed.

The research provides interdisciplinary training to PhD students and offer summer research experience to undergraduate student.  The education materials developed will help to disseminate this research throughout many different engineering domains, provide training to underrepresented groups, and raise engineering awareness in K-12.  Results from topology optimization are visually appealing to attract the attention of students to engineering opportunities provided by this work.


This project brings together the close collaboration among the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) Center for Nanoscale Materials (CNM), the cleanroom facilities at NU (NUFAB), and the nano-imprinting system at Northwestern. It will help to integrate and expand the nano-facbrication resources in the great Chicago area.
